content.verbatim_text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.
content.plain_text: Assignment clauses are vital during business sales, acquisitions, or similar transactions. Requiring consent for assignment can complicate and delay deals, and neglecting the clause during negotiation can lead to the non-transferring party leveraging consent for concessions.
content.expert_insight: This underscores the strategic importance of assignment clauses beyond mere legal formality. Proactive negotiation can prevent significant hurdles and costs during M&A activities.
content.justification: Provides context on the importance and potential pitfalls of assignment clauses.
content.implication_company: Poorly negotiated assignment clauses can complicate or sidetrack future M&A transactions and lead to unexpected costs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may gain leverage if the assignment clause requires their consent for a company's M&A activities.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the criticality and potential negative impacts.
content.text: Assignment clauses can become critical in a sale of business, acquisition or other similar transaction. Having an obligation to obtain consents for assigning contracts from present contract parties can complicate and potentially sidetrack the contemplated transaction. Failure to pay close attention to the language of the assignment clause while the contract is being negotiated may also create an opportunity for the nontransferring party to later extort concessions in return to its consent to the contract assignment.

content.verbatim_text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must ensure contracts provide maximum flexibility for assignment without supplier consent to any successor entity (for reorganization) or at least allow free assignment to an affiliate (for share purchase reorganizations).
content.expert_insight: This is a key strategic objective for Zebracorp to maintain operational and structural flexibility, especially in the context of corporate restructuring or M&A. Prioritizing this in contract negotiations is essential.
content.conditions: Applicable to all contracts Zebracorp concludes.
content.justification: Ensures flexibility for corporate reorganizations and acquisitions.
content.implication_company: Maintains corporate flexibility, reduces friction and costs during reorganizations and share purchases.
content.implication_supplier: Limits supplier's ability to block or demand concessions during Zebracorp's corporate restructuring.
content.source_insight: Explicitly stated as 'important to make sure'.
content.text: It is for these reasons important to make sure that each contract we conclude gives us the maximum flexibility to assign without the supplier’s consent to any succeeding entity to Zebracorp (in case of a reorganization), or at the minimum allow free assignment by Zebracorp to an affiliate (which accomplishes the same ability for re-organization if Zebracorp is acquired through a share purchase at the shareholder level).

content.verbatim_text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.
content.plain_text: If a supplier refuses Zebracorp the right to assign to an affiliate, the contract must, at minimum, stipulate that assignment approval will not be 'arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed'.
content.expert_insight: This provides a fallback position, ensuring that even if explicit free assignment is not granted, the supplier cannot use consent as an arbitrary blocking mechanism. This aligns with 'commercially reasonable efforts' principles.
content.conditions: If supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant Zebracorp the right to assign to an affiliate.
content.justification: Prevents suppliers from arbitrarily blocking assignments, ensuring a reasonable consent process.
content.implication_company: Provides a legal basis to challenge unreasonable withholding of consent, maintaining some flexibility.
content.implication_supplier: Requires suppliers to have legitimate, non-arbitrary reasons for withholding assignment consent.
content.source_insight: Stated as 'at the very minimum have a note saying'.
content.text: In the event the supplier/subcontractor refuses to grant us right to assign to an affiliate, then we should at the very minimum have a note saying that the approval for the assignment will not be “arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed”.

content.verbatim_text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially. Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's assignment rights should explicitly include partial assignment and, ideally, a right to 'split' contracts, especially for business line divestments, to ensure continued use by both Zebracorp and any acquirer.
content.expert_insight: This foresight is crucial for managing complex corporate transactions like divestitures, allowing for precise allocation of contractual rights and obligations without needing to renegotiate entirely new contracts.
content.conditions: When negotiating assignment clauses.
content.justification: Provides flexibility for partial transfers and business line divestitures, ensuring continuity of contract use.
content.implication_company: Facilitates business line divestments and partial transfers, avoiding the need for new contracts and potential disruptions.
content.implication_supplier: May require suppliers to manage contracts with multiple parties post-split, but ensures continued business.
content.source_insight: Stated as 'should include' and 'would be recommended to expressly agree'.
content.text: Our right to assign each contract should include also partial assignment of the contract. In many cases such partial assignment right is implicit from the right to assign the entire agreement, but it would be recommended to expressly agree on a right to assign the agreement either in its entirety or partially. Ideally we should also seek to secure a right to ‘split’ the respective contract, in case of divestment of a Zebracorp business line so that both Zebracorp and any third party acquirer of any specific Zebracorp business line will continue to be able to use the same contract.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp should avoid agreeing to mutual assignment rights with suppliers. It is preferable to waive Zebracorp's own assignment right than to allow suppliers to freely assign contracts to third parties without Zebracorp's consent.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation strategy. Allowing suppliers to freely assign could introduce unknown or unqualified parties, undermining due diligence and potentially jeopardizing Zebracorp's supply chain and quality standards.
content.conditions: When negotiating assignment clauses with suppliers/subcontractors.
content.justification: Protects Zebracorp from unknown or unqualified third-party suppliers, preserving the integrity of its supplier selection process.
content.implication_company: Maintains control over supplier relationships and mitigates risks associated with unknown third-party performance.
content.implication_supplier: Restricts suppliers' ability to transfer their contractual obligations without Zebracorp's approval.
content.source_insight: Explicitly states 'we would not wish to agree' and 'we would rather forego'.
content.text: Please note that, when negotiating the assignment clause with our suppliers/subcontractors, we would not wish to agree to a mutual assignment right. This means that in most cases we would rather forego our right to assign than to agree on any language that would allow the supplier/subcontractor to freely assign the agreement to a third party without our consent.

content.verbatim_text: This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.
content.plain_text: The rationale for restricting supplier assignment is that each supplier undergoes a rigorous selection process to ensure their capability to meet commitments. Free assignment would bypass this process, potentially allowing suppliers to evade critical obligations.
content.expert_insight: This justification is strong and should be communicated clearly to suppliers during negotiations to explain the asymmetry in assignment rights. It links directly to risk management and supply chain integrity.
content.justification: Explains why Zebracorp does not want to agree to mutual assignment rights with suppliers.
content.implication_company: Reinforces the importance of the supplier selection process and protects against unqualified third parties.
content.implication_supplier: Clarifies Zebracorp's position and the reasoning behind restrictions on supplier assignment.
content.source_insight: Provides the 'because' for the preceding guideline.
content.text: This is because each of our suppliers have gone through a selection process where each supplier has been deemed financially and otherwise able to meet their eventual contractual commitments towards Zebracorp. Allowing the supplier to freely substitute itself to another third party would negate the entire selection process, and in worst case enable the supplier to effectively walk away from critical contractual commitments.

content.verbatim_text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's right to assign must be unconditional, ensuring it does not remain jointly liable with the assignee for the assigned contract. The assignment should provide a clean exit, releasing Zebracorp from all liabilities under the assigned agreement.
content.expert_insight: This is paramount for liability management. Remaining jointly liable defeats a key purpose of assignment (transferring burden) and exposes Zebracorp to risks from the assignee's performance. A clean exit is non-negotiable.
content.conditions: When Zebracorp assigns a contract.
content.justification: Ensures Zebracorp is fully released from obligations and liabilities upon assignment, preventing residual liability.
content.implication_company: Minimizes post-assignment liability and ensures a complete transfer of risk to the assignee.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier will deal solely with the assignee after a valid assignment by Zebracorp, assuming Zebracorp is fully released.
content.source_insight: Stated as 'should not be made subject to' and 'should be unconditional'.
content.text: Also note that our right to assign the contract should not be made subject to us remaining jointly liable for the assigned contract together with the assignee. The assignment should be unconditional in the sense that Zebracorp will not accept liability for any commitments made by any third party assignee. The assignment should also provide a clean exit for Zebracorp in the sense that Zebracorp will not remain jointly liable under the assigned agreement with the new contracting party.

content.verbatim_text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.
content.plain_text: When structuring corporate acquisitions, parties choose between asset purchases (requiring specific contract assignments and due diligence) or acquiring the entire company (share purchase or merger). In share purchases/mergers, contracts are not assigned to a new legal entity; only the ownership of the existing entity changes, which generally does not require third-party consent, contrary to common belief.
content.expert_insight: This provides crucial context for M&A legal strategy, distinguishing between asset and share deals regarding contract transfer implications. It clarifies a common misconception about 'change of control' versus actual assignment.
content.justification: Explains the different ways corporate transactions are structured and their implications for contract assignment and consent requirements.
content.implication_company: Informs strategic decisions on M&A structuring to minimize contract assignment complications.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that a change in ownership of their contracting party (via share sale/merger) typically does not trigger assignment consent rights unless explicitly agreed.
content.source_insight: Provides detailed explanation of 'Assignment by Operation of Law' context.
content.text: When planning acquisitions or such other corporate transactions, the acquiring party will usually have to consider how it prefers to structure the transactions. The acquiring party can either elect to purchase the target company's assets (which enables the acquiring party to pick and choose only the assets and contracts they desire) or alternatively it may elect to acquire the entire company. In an asset sale, the need for contract-by-contract due diligence, would become particularly important since each contract needs to be specifically assigned in the context of asset sale. The acquiring party would generally be able to avoid such issues by electing to acquire the entire share capital of the target company (thereby making it a subsidiary of the acquiring entity) or by merging together with the target company. In the latter case (i.e. when the acquiring party obtains all outstanding shares in the target company and makes the acquired company its subsidiary), there is strictly speaking no need to obtain a consent for the assignment of the related contracts. This is because the contracts in themselves are not ‘assigned’ to any new legal entity but only the owner of the existing legal entity changes. Contrary to widely held belief, changes in ownership do not generally require the other contracting party’s consent. In companies whose shares are stock-listed the ownership changes each day the market is open.

content.verbatim_text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.
content.plain_text: Assignment by operation of law refers to the automatic vesting of all assets, liabilities, and contracts in a merged or acquiring entity during an acquisition or merger, without requiring consent from the opposing contracting party.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental legal principle in many jurisdictions, simplifying corporate restructurings by avoiding the need for individual contract consents, unless specifically overridden by contract.

content.text: An acquisition or a merger would in most countries serve to "vest" all assets and liabilities including contracts automatically to a merging and surviving entity or the acquiring party, as the case may be, by ‘operation of law’ without a need to obtain a consent from the opposing party.

content.verbatim_text: The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent. Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates.
content.plain_text: Parties can contractually agree that an ownership change (e.g., over 50% of shares) requires consent. Clauses prohibiting transfer by merger or 'change of control' are common, especially in supplier templates, making any such assignment ineffective without prior written consent.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the tension between legal default rules (assignment by operation of law) and specific contractual overrides. Companies must be vigilant for these 'change of control' clauses, as they can significantly impact M&A flexibility.
content.justification: Provides context on contractual provisions that can override the general principle of assignment by operation of law.
content.implication_company: Must carefully review contracts for 'change of control' clauses that could complicate M&A, even if assignment by operation of law is generally permitted.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can include clauses to gain control over who their contracting party is, even in cases of corporate restructuring.
content.source_insight: Explains that parties can agree to specific conditions and provides an example clause.
content.text: The parties are of course free to agree between themselves that a ownership change of certain magnitude (in e.g. affecting over 50 % of all outstanding shares) will require the other party’s consent. Also, clauses that prohibit any transfer by any kind of merger or "change of control" are not uncommon. Below is an example of such clause: “Any attempted assignment of this [Agreement] whether directly, by change in control or by operation of law, shall be ineffective unless effected with the other party’s prior written consent”. Variants of the above provision can be found in particular in suppliers’ own contract templates.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction. In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's stance is that assignment by operation of law should not require supplier consent. In most cases, Zebracorp should reject clauses demanding such consent, as they complicate M&A. For critical R&D contracts where Zebracorp imposes assignment restrictions on suppliers, it's preferable to remove the clause entirely rather than agree to a mutual restriction that would limit Zebracorp's own assignment rights.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical directive for protecting Zebracorp's M&A flexibility. The justification regarding timing and cost impacts of consent requirements is very strong. The advice to abandon a clause rather than make it mutual in specific contexts is a pragmatic, high-impact negotiation strategy.
content.conditions: When negotiating assignment clauses, especially concerning assignment by operation of law and in critical R&D contracts.
content.justification: Provisions requiring consent for assignment by operation of law complicate and impede mergers and acquisitions, impacting timing and cost. Maintaining asymmetry in R&D contracts protects Zebracorp's strategic interests.
content.implication_company: Ensures smoother, less costly M&A processes for Zebracorp and protects its flexibility in strategic R&D partnerships.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will generally not have a right to consent to Zebracorp's assignment by operation of law, unless a specific, non-mutual clause is agreed upon.
content.source_insight: Explicitly states 'Zebracorp’s firm view' and 'we should reject'.
content.text: Zebracorp’s firm view is that assignment of contract by operation of law should not require the supplier’s consent, and in most cases we should reject any language that requires us to seek consent from other party in connection with transfer of agreement by operation of law. This is largely due to the fact that these type of provisions are likely to cause complications when planning mergers, acquisitions or such other transactions. For example, if Zebracorp was planning on forming a merger with another company, we would work from the assumption that our contracts with our suppliers/subcontractors would be automatically transferred to the new merged entity by operation of law without the need seek consents from our supplier base. An assignment restriction described above is likely to impact the timing, cost and our ability to consummate a "smooth" merger or such other transaction. In those critical R&D contracts and the like where we do impose these very same assignment restrictions on our suppliers, it would be better to abandon the entire clause than to agree to mutual clause that would restrict Zebracorp from assigning the contract.

content.verbatim_text: The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp can justify non-mutual assignment provisions to suppliers by explaining the asymmetric customer-supplier relationship. To make the contract more acceptable, Zebracorp can allow suppliers to transfer by operation of law to parties that are not direct competitors.
content.expert_insight: These are practical negotiation tactics. Framing the non-mutuality within the customer-supplier dynamic is often effective. The competitor carve-out is a smart concession that addresses a supplier's need for flexibility without compromising Zebracorp's core competitive interests.
content.justification: Provides strategies for negotiating non-mutual assignment clauses with suppliers.
content.implication_company: Helps in successful negotiation of favorable assignment terms while maintaining supplier relationships.
content.implication_supplier: Offers a potential concession (transfer to non-competitors) while still restricting transfer to direct competitors.
content.source_insight: Provides advice on how to explain and make contracts more palatable.
content.text: The fact that Zebracorp is not willing to make these assignment provisions mutual can often be explained to the supplier by the asymmetric contractual relationship i.e. that of the customer and the supplier. In most cases, we can make the contract more palatable to the supplier by agreeing to allow the supplier transfer the contract by operation of law to any party that is not a direct competitor of Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: Under UK laws, an assignment of rights under a contract is normally restricted solely to the benefits of the contract. Where a party wishes to transfer both the benefit and burden of the contract without any residual liability (as is usually the case), the assignment of the contract would generally needs to be done by way of a novation.
content.plain_text: Under UK law, assignment typically transfers only the benefits of a contract. To transfer both benefits and burdens without residual liability, a novation is generally required.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical distinction for contracts governed by UK law. Misunderstanding this can lead to unintended residual liabilities for the assignor, as a simple 'assignment' under UK law does not automatically release the original party from its obligations.

content.verbatim_text: For this reason, when the agreement is governed by UK laws, it is useful to specifically mention that the agreement is not only assigned but also novated, and the transfer of the rights and obligations may require the execution of a specific novation agreement.
content.plain_text: For agreements governed by UK law, it is advisable to explicitly state that the contract is both assigned and novated, and that a separate novation agreement might be necessary for the transfer of rights and obligations.
content.expert_insight: This is a best practice for UK-governed contracts to ensure a complete and effective transfer of both benefits and burdens, explicitly avoiding residual liability for the original party.

content.verbatim_text: Please speak to a member of the Legal & Compliance team to obtain the appropriate templates/language. Due to the prevalence of UK origin contract documentation, the term novation and novation agreements in general are often (incorrectly) used in other jurisdictions as well when the parties should be talking about contract transfer or assignment. This in itself is not issue in the majority of cases, as most jurisdictions will recognize the term novation to mean the same as transfer of a contract.
content.plain_text: Consult the Legal & Compliance team for suitable templates/language. While 'novation' is often (incorrectly) used outside UK law, most jurisdictions generally understand it to mean contract transfer or assignment, so it's usually not an issue.
content.expert_insight: This is practical advice for internal processes and clarifies a common linguistic nuance in international contract drafting. While 'novation' might be technically incorrect outside the UK, its common understanding often mitigates legal risk.
content.justification: Provides guidance on internal resources and clarifies common misunderstandings regarding the term 'novation' across jurisdictions.
content.implication_company: Ensures proper legal review and use of correct terminology, minimizing potential ambiguities.

content.verbatim_text: Changes of Company Name. Companies have the freedom to change the trade name that they use to conduct their business. When changing the name of the company, the registered legal entity which can be identified through each company’s individual registration number remains the same. These type of changes in the name or registered addresses of a company are not regarded as assignments so long as the underlying legal entity remains the same and only the name/address of the company changes. Accordingly, there is no need to seek or grant consent to such change of name/registered address alone. A unilateral notification of the name change to the other contracting party should be sufficient. While it is recommended to clarify the name change in future contract amendments, strictly speaking this is not necessary. The name change can be mentioned in a contract amendment in e.g. by adding a following note in brackets after the name of the contracting party: e.g. “(formerly known as Zebracorp Space)” or, in short, “(f/k/a Zebracorp Space)”.
content.plain_text: Changes in a company's name or registered address are not considered assignments if the underlying legal entity (identified by its registration number) remains the same. Therefore, no consent is required; a unilateral notification suffices. While clarifying the name change in future contract amendments (e.g., using '(formerly known as X)' or '(f/k/a X)') is recommended, it's not strictly necessary.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies a common point of confusion. It's important to distinguish between a change in legal entity (which may trigger assignment clauses) and a mere administrative name/address change. The advice on notification and optional amendment language is practical.
content.justification: Clarifies that company name/address changes are not assignments and do not require consent.
content.implication_company: Streamlines administrative updates without triggering complex assignment processes or requiring counterparty consent.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that a name/address change of Zebracorp does not grant them a right to consent or renegotiate the contract.
content.source_insight: Provides information and recommendations regarding company name changes.

content.verbatim_text: “Except as otherwise provided in this [Agreement], neither party may assign, novate, delegate, or transfer this [Agreement], or any of its individual rights or obligations under this [Agreement], without the prior written approval of the other Party, which approval will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. Any attempted assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer without the necessary approval is void. However, [Zebracorp] may, without the prior written consent of the [Supplier], unconditionally assign, novate, delegate or transfer any or all of its rights and obligations under this [Agreement], in whole, in part, or through a splitting of the [Agreement], to any Affiliate or to any acquirer of a Zebracorp business line to which this contract relates. As of the effective date of the assignment, novation, delegation, or transfer, the assignee entity(ies) assumes all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement], and [Zebracorp] is unconditionally released and discharged from all of the relevant rights, obligations and liabilities of the [Agreement]. [Supplier] will work cooperatively with [Zebracorp] and the assignee entity(ies) to ensure a smooth and orderly transition.”
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's preferred assignment clause states that generally, neither party can assign/novate/delegate/transfer without the other's prior written approval (not to be unreasonably withheld/delayed), and unauthorized attempts are void. However, Zebracorp may unconditionally assign/novate/delegate/transfer all or part of its rights/obligations, or split the agreement, to any Affiliate or acquirer of a relevant business line without supplier consent. Upon such transfer, the assignee assumes all relevant rights/obligations/liabilities, and Zebracorp is unconditionally released. The supplier must cooperate for a smooth transition.
content.expert_insight: This clause is a comprehensive example of Zebracorp's preferred position, incorporating key protections: general mutual consent (with reasonableness), specific unilateral rights for Zebracorp (affiliates, business line acquirers, partial/split assignments), unconditional release of Zebracorp, and a cooperation obligation for the supplier. It effectively balances flexibility for Zebracorp with a degree of control for the supplier.
content.justification: Provides a concrete example of Zebracorp's preferred contractual language for assignment clauses.
content.implication_company: Serves as a template for negotiating assignment clauses that align with Zebracorp's strategic interests.
content.implication_supplier: Illustrates the specific terms suppliers can expect in Zebracorp's contracts regarding assignment.
content.source_insight: Explicitly presented as 'An example of our preferred assignment clause'.
